body: Lgtm
There should be only one commit in this pr. So no merges indeed.

I am on it, I do not see any problem here with Python 2.7, I'll add a unit test to cover the fact get_url_prefix returns a str in python 2.7.

`url_prefix.__native__()` does not work, url_prefix is a unicode string in my tests. I'll update this PR asap

I have found the issue and fixed it. It works in when the string is empty and when it is not, in python 2.7. 

So now should work in python 2.7, 3.5 and 3.6, at least.

I have some difficulties to add unit tests, I'll try to do something this afternoon.
fixed by #2871

@Fokko Would love to get your feedback on this, here are some of my thoughts:

I placed the sensors under `from airflow.operators.[sensor] import [Sensor]`, in order to avoid working with the deprecated AirflowImporter and avoid duplicating code. I maintained the deprecated version, `from airflow.operators import [Sensor]`.

Alternatively, I can create a separate package, outside of `operators/`, called `sensors/`, and leave `sensors.py` in `operators/` with a deprecation warning, while dispersing the classes in `sensors.py` into separate files in the `sensors/` package. The result would be imports that look like from `airflow.sensors.[sensor] import [Sensor]` and maintaining the deprecated `from airflow.operators import [Sensor]`. 

The difference is whether we want to treat sensors as a feature separate from operators, regardless that they inherit from an operator. Additionally, code would be duplicated in both `sensors.py` and the class files, until 2.0.
lgtm! good catch.

Hi @andyxhadji 

I also started on the PR, but I'm fine if you want to pick this up. I've created a PR to easily see the changes: https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/2875

I strongly feel that we should refactor it a bit more by creating a `airflow.sensors`, like we have with `airflow.contrib.sensors`:
https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/tree/master/airflow/contrib/sensors

This also means that the tests should be split from the big `sensors.py`:
https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/blob/master/tests/operators/sensors.py
The same accounts for the `tests/core.py` which also contains a couple of tests for the sensors. This would also be beneficial for the code quality since this file is around 2k5 lines.

What do you think? Cheers

I suggest _not_ putting sensors in airflow.sensors but rather airflow.operators.sensors. Better for the logging framework :). Or make sure logging stays functional for airflow.sensors.

Although as they derive from BaseOperator they should be fine, but it gets a bit fuzzy if we do so.

Looks like you've made more progress than I have, so I closed mine. I'm
happy to help with any part, lots of grunt work here (especially all the
linting for the touched files, e.g. tests/core.py). Just let me know a
portion I can run with!

I was struggling with operators.sensors vs. just .sensors as well - because
sensors inherit from a base operator (and operate as one), keeping them
nested makes sense as well. Agree that whatever structure is chosen,
though, should be consistent with contrib/.

Not sure how feasible it is, however, to maintain deprecated import
structure if we create a sensors package inside operators/ (can we
simultaneously support `from airflow.operators.sensors import [Sensor]` and
`from airflow.operators.sensors.[sensor] import [Sensor]`)?

Hi @brokenjacobs 

Thanks for the contribution, very nice. Would it be possible to create a test for this? Since it is not in the contrib folder, a tests is required. I'm aware of the fact that there are no tests for the presto hook at all, but this would be highly appreciated.

Cheers, Fokko

Thanks for the response Trevor. I mistakenly rebased some WIP changes to the head of my fork, hence the addition of the pull and acknowledge operators. I will get that cleaned up. I intend to submit a separate JIRA issue for adding Push/Ack functionality in the form of SensorOperators.

If you're OK with it, I can update the JIRA description to reflect the inclusion of new operators in addition to the hook methods. I'll get everything else cleaned up as well.

cc @bolkedebruin 

I also have a patch against the v1-9-stable branch as this one doesn't apply without conflicts there: https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/compare/v1-9-stable...ashb:AIRFLOW-1916-dont-upload-logs-twice-v1-9-stable?expand=1 -- haven't opened a PR for this but I can if it would be helpful.
I would prefer something like `self.is_direct` or `self.is_raw` on TaskInstance. This can be checked by the handlers directly instead of having it set by `set_context`. Keeps things simpler as well.
Random test timeouts :(

> `Δ = absolute <relative> (impact)`, `ø = not affected`, `? = missing data`
> Powered by [Codecov](https://codecov.io/gh/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/2883?src=pr&el=footer). Last update [a3c5783...c23aefa](https://codecov.io/gh/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/2883?src=pr&el=lastupdated). Read the [comment docs](https://docs.codecov.io/docs/pull-request-comments).

This makes it a non-backwards compatible change going from 1.9.0 to 1.9.1. It would be nice if we supported both styles for at least one point release.

Django's approach of "if you have no deprecation warnings now then if you upgrade it will still work" is one I like. It makes upgrading easier to my mind if you can upgrade then fix the issues, rather than having to upgrade the deployment and fix issues in lock-step.

API wise it could look like `conf.get('celery', 'worker_concurrency', deprecated='celeryd_concurrency')`
(closing and re-opening to get travis to re-test.)
Tests are still failing for what I'm fairly sure are spurious reasons - sqlite variants pass, but mysql and postgres don't. At least not both together

I’m not sure if I would consider this to be really backward incompatible. It is not so that you have to change a 100 dags. 

Your suggestion for the configuration does sound like a good idea.

My idea around "backwards compatible" is I can take a currently running system that isn't issuing  any deprecation warnings, upgrade the version of airflow and have it run without making any other changes. I realise this is quite an extreme view though.

This is better discussed on the mailing list. I'll do that (though next week).
Gotcha. My idea of backwards compatible is more along the lines of FreeBSD. API/ABI compatible, but config changes can happen and are in UPDATING.
Error is due to silly timeout. All other builds passed. Merging.
@TrevorEdwards would you mind taking a look?
